EDITORIAL.
711, ill NC

T last, we believe, the "Open, sesame" has been discovered for the
iron-clad doors holding the entrance to our much coveted residence
*****•••
at Homewood! It is gratifying and encouraging to have a number
of prominent men, headed by President Remsen, come before the
public and place our needs squarely before them. This is the only
*
way ever to accomplish our great end. With money constantly pouring
into the educational treasury—coffers we may say—there is no
*
WIFICIIIICV,AW*41 •
doubt that our share is locked up some place. The point is to get
lf
ralg 4/
:
those men of insight, who know accurately and feel deeply the ad4L
10 'Pi
vantages not only to the University, but, also, to every citizen of
Baltimore City and Maryland, to open their mouths and to tell the public what they should
do to help their own sons, for, alas! they not seldom are blind to their own good.
Prominent men recently have called attention to a few facts which have a world of
meaning in then, and which should not be allowed to die down,—but should be used, if we
have to do the blowing ourselves,—to kindle a flame of enthusiasm, which will mightly stir
the people. "The position of the Johns Hopkins among other great universities of this country is unique. With the small sums, comparatively speaking, at its disposal, it has maintained from the start, a position as one of the greatest graduate and medical institutions, not
only of this country, but, also, of the world." "I feel that the Johns Hopkins University
and Hospital
is the biggest asset that Baltimore possesses.'' ``Its standing in the educational world is unquestioned, and now, that the opportunity is afforded to
make it bigger and better
Baltimoreans ought to be the first to come forward in the advocacy of the plan." From this it is plain that there are men who, if they
themselves have not the money, would be perfectly willing to organize themselves to see that
the necessary funds are raised.
The opportunity is at hand. The sum is not a large one,—even for Marylanders to
raise,—considering what the Woman's College and the Y. M. C. A. have done. Let us all—
faculty, alumni, students—awake! Let usfind out plainly ourselves what is the future for us
if we are given room to expand, let us keep it constantly before the public, and replace, "It
will be a nice thing to get to Homeward," by "We are•determined to get there, and that
at once."

RESIDENT GILMAN, in enumerating the branches of knowledge
with which an educated man should be acquainted recommended a
practical acquaintance with two modern languages—French and
German. No one could dispute this opinion, for whether he be a
student of Philosophy, of Physics, of Latin or Greek, or, even, of
English literature he knows that stores of information are behind
doors opening only to German and French keys.
Now, if an instructor were asked what is the greatest help in
getting a hold on a language, he would, doubtless, answer "An
ability to understand the language when spoken. Go to France, to
people
talk, and, then, when you pick up a book you will begin to
the
Germany, listen to
understand what your foreign friend wishes to tell you." But how many of the students can
take this wholesome advice? Only a small part. For this reason it is, perhaps, that the University turns the table, and tries to bring France and Germany to us. Monsieur Janier gives us a
number of lectures and, following him, comes Dr. Kiihnemann, from both of whom we derive
no little help. Hence, as undergraduate students, we can see that if we could listen regularly
to French and German, it would be a question of but a short time till everyone would understand, at least, a simple discourse and be able to speak more or less fluently.
We cannot expect, however; constant imfiortations, nor do we think it necessary. Among
the faculty are men who are either German or French by birth, or who have sufficiently mastered
one or the other language to feel no hesitation in talking or reading to us for several hours a
week.
•
Various plans could be adopted, the talks or readings could be graded to suit the
vocabularies of the hearers; regular attendance could be secured by making this a part of the
regular course and requiring a brief synopsis of the lecture,—anything that would insure a more
thorough acquaintance with the languages during the undergraduate years.
We feel that this is a real need, and would respectfully request the faculty to take this
matter into consideration.

THE COCK FIGHT.
What call you the king of sports, boys
The highest, by far, of all our joys?
When fancy-free and out for fun,
Is it not cock-fighting, ten to one?
On a blustery, windy winter's night
When no one's looking, and no one's in sight,
Down to some dreary barn we go,
Where round about howl the winds, and blow.
Securely fastening the barn door,
We throw our cocks upon the floor.
Tnen flash of steel in the din lamp-light,
A click of steel against brain,
Triumphant crow of the victor cock,—
And all is still again.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE THIRTY-FIRST ANNIVERSARY

CELEBRATION.
The audience that assembled in McCoy
Hall on February 22nd to see the commeration exercises found a notable assembly. Of
the five divisions of the procession that filed
in between the lines of undergraduate students,
the first, directly following Chief Marshal
Edward B. Mathews, consisted of President
Remsen and Governor Warfield, walking
abreast. Behind these were Mr. R. Brent
Keyser, President of the board of trustees of
the University, and Cardinal Gibbons, Mr.
Blanchard Randall, President of the Baltimore
Chamber of Commerce, and Attorney-General
Charles J. Bonaparte, President Emeritus
Daniel C. Gilman and Professor Hannis
Taylor, Mr. Joshua Levering and Mayor
Timanus, Dean Edward H. Griffin and Mr.
William H. Buckler. Following these were
the other members of the board of trustees,
and the faculty of the university. The second
division was made up of the alumni and
candidates for degrees; the third consisted of
the graduate students in philosophy; the
fourth, of the students in medicine; and the
fifth, of the undergraduates.
The musical program was under the direction
of Mr. Edwin Litchfield Turnbull, who conducted an orchestra of twenty-seven pieces.
National airs began to be heard from the lobby
as the procession, at 10.45 a. m., proceeded
to the main hall, and, during the intervals
between the exercises, the orchestra rendered
several carefully prepared selections.
After the offering of the invocation by the
Reverend Edward Barnes Niver, rector of
Christ Church, President Remsen introduced
the orator of the day, Professor Hannis Taylor,
formerly United States Minister to Spain and
a member of the committee on the settlement
of the Spanish war claims.
Professor Taylor's speech was a strong and
interesting presentation of the "Relation of
the South to Pending Problems." In regard
to the question of controlling by legislation
those bewildering millions that lie at the disposal of private individuals, he said: "It is
the States alone that have the constitutional
power to deal with such questions, and, in the
present condition of rapid inter-communication, the necessary concert of action is not at

all impossible. No nobler work could be
undertaken by the American Bar Association,
which has the machinery necessary for the
making of an immediate beginning."
When the selection, which followed this
address, had been concluded by the orchestra,
the degree of Doctor of Philosophy was
was awarded to Mr. Alfred Allan Kerns
(Randolph-Mown, '98) and to Mr. Louis
Bernard Wolfenson (University of Wisconsin,
'01). It was also announced that Miss
Straight had received her degree of Doctor of
Medicine.
When the degrees had been awarded, President Remsen rose to read the list of announcements. In regard to money for moving to
Homewood, Dr. Remsen saki emphatically
that he had nothing definite to announce.
However, he went on to say that there are
'things in the air,' and it remains for us only
to pull them down. It was also announced
that Dr. John C. Hilde had won the Henrico
medallion, his dissertation being upon the
"Early Diplomatic Relations of the United
States with Spain."
Mr. William H. Buckler, as chairman of
the committee on Homewood, reported that
an accurate togographical survey of the whole
property had been made, that the athletic
field was now rapidly rounding into shape
and will be in condition for foot-ball in the
fall, and, also, that the plans have been made
for a series of botanical gardens.
A cablegram, received from Professors
Wilson, Mayoffin, Moore and Spencer, Hopkins men engaged in research in the classical
school at Rome, was then read, as was, also,
an announcement of a gift for the purchase of
archaeological specimens from Italy.
In the evening the Hopkins Alumni held
their annual banquet at the Merchant's Club,
where, according to all accounts, they had a
most enjoyable reunion.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

INTERCOLLEGIATE CONFERENCE.
Levering Hall has, again, been selected as
the place of meeting of an Intercollegiate
Missionary Conference. The Conference will
convene on Saturday, March 9, and continue
till Sunday evening.
Delegates have been invited from the following institutions: Western Maryland,
Maryland Agricultural and Delaware Colleges;
George Washington University, Jacob Tome
Institute, Charlotte Hall School, Wilmington
Conference Academy, New Windsor College,
United States Naval Academy. St. John's
College, Woman's Colleges of Baltimore,
Frederick and Lutherville. Besides these, all
the local medical schools will be represented.
The speakers at the Conference will be Mr.
Fennell P. Turner, Secretary of the Student
Volunteer Movement; Mr. Staub, one of the
traveling secretaries of the Movement; Dr.
Marion J. Kline, Secretary of the Lutheran
Board of Foreign Missions, and others.
The program promises to be one of unusual
interest. The opening session, at 2.30 p. m.,
Saturday, will be devoted to addresses and
discussions, and will be followed by a supper
for the official delegates. In the evening
there will be a public meeting for students.
The Sunday morning session will be held in
conjunction with the Students' Bible Class of
Mt. Vernon M. E. Church at 10 o'clock. At
3 p. m., in Levering Hall, will be held a session for Student Volunteers. The evening
session at 7 o'clock will be held in the chapel
of the First M. E. Church.
Hopkins students are invited, especially, to
the Saturday evening, Sunday morning and
evening sessions.
The many phases of missionary work will
be treated in this Conference. Mr. Turner's
wide experience enables him to speak authoritatively on missionary work in all foreign
lands. The other speakers will deal with
mission study which has become so popular in
the last few years and with the training of
Volunteers.

Mr. Robert E. Speer, the noted speaker to
college students, will preach at Brown
Memorial Presbyterian Church on March 17.

Seats will be reserved for students until 7.45
p. m. No man can afford to miss hearing
him.

CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION
REUNION.

MEMBERS'

The annual reunion of members of the
Christian Association was held in Levering
Hall February 20th. The fellows and a number of the faculty joined in an informal social
evening. Drs. Ballagh and Mathews gave
interesting talks, Dr. Brush presided. The
Mandolin Club played in good style, after
which all sang Hopkins songs, and enjoyed
refreshments.

BIBLE AND MISSION STUDY CLASSES.
Three Bible classes are meeting regularly
each week, one of which is under the auspices
of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew.
Two mission study classes have been
started. One under the leadership of Dr. L.
C. Ballet is studying Dr. Grose's book,
"Aliens or Americans ?" This book deals
with the problems of immigration and their
bearing upon home missions. The other
class is studying the latest work in foreign
lands. It is being conducted by the General
Secretary.
The attention of Hopkins students is called
to the morning Chapel exercises. Every man
is invited to attend. A little effort will be required to get down by 8.45 a. m., but "get
the habit," and it soon becomes easy.

The Student Handbooks received this year
from other colleges will be placed on exhibition in Levering Hall.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE SEA.
"The light, and sound, and darkness of the sea."
[Swinburne.]

I.
When the gods on high had created the land
And gave life to the sounding deep,
And ordained the day as a time for work,
And night as a time for sleep,
They gave man joy that he might laugh,
And sorrow that he might weep.
Thanksgiving arose from valleys and hills,
And caves echo praises again;
Creation rejoiced, and joyful sang,—
Save the Might of the murmuring main;—
The gods had created and formed it;
Tried to rule it—but ever in vain.
Though the mists render thanks as they rise
from the vale,
And clouds as they float o'er the hill,
Though the wind giveth praises aloud and
afar,
And the violet lowly and still,
The sound of the sea, with its surges and
swell,
Bends not to the heavenly will.
IV.
But ever and ever, while dashing in spray,
Or roaring tumultous afar;
In the brightness of noon, in night and in
storm,
By the light of a lingering star,
They rise up against the decree of the gods
In melodious thunderous war!
—S. C. C.

THE POOR EDITOR.
At a recent editorial convention a member
offered the following toast: "To save an
editor from starvation, take his paper and
pay for it promptly. To save him from bankruptcy, advertise in his paper liberally. To
save him from despair, send him every news
item of which you can get hold. To save
him from wrath, write your correspondence
plainly on one side of the sheet and send it in
as early as possible. To save him from mistakes, bury him. Dead people are the only
ones who never make any mistakes."—Exchange.

THE CANADIAN GUIDE.
He knows no power to bid him stay,
Where'er he will—there lies his way.
No social ties have bound his soul—
Within himself, his life, his goal.
His hearth the camp-fire in the gloam,
The star-watched wilderness his home.
His is that freedom large, sublime,
That was before the count of time.
His strength is as the hills secure,
And like the hills he can endure.
Might, courage. honesty—he sees
In men no virtues, saving these.
No learning has he, yet would I
Fain rise to his philosophy.
He knows no music save the wild
Strange songs he heard when once a child.
Or those weird tunes the logmen sing,
Borne down the river with the spring.
And yet a savage poetry lies
On his few words, and in his eyes.
Whence came he? that lie cannot say—
"Somewhere to Northward and away."
And whither goes? He cannot tell,
For him the present time is well.
He cares not for the passing years,
Their blight he neither knows nor fears.
For him 'tis fated not to die
A weak man's death, but, 'neath the sky,
To sink upon some roaring flood,
And rise unsullied to his God.
—W. B. M.

THE POSTMAN.
The postman is a funny man
Who never does things right;
The things he brings on time we wish
Had never met our sight.
The bills and such and postal cards
That bear the college seal
Are always brought in perfect time
With sadly misplaced zeal.
But checks from home and notes from 'Her"
Don't come in such a drive,
And though we're sure that they were sent
They somehow don't arrive.—Lampoon.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

MODERN LOVE.
(With apologies to Mr. George Meredith.)

She was rather an unsophisticated little
lady, and decidedy ingenious. For a long
time Arthur Hamilton had fancied himself in
love with her, and she took little pains to conceal the pleasure which his conventional
protestations of adoration" gave her, although at first she was quite heart-free herself. Arthur found himself, as he grow older,
coming to the conclusion that the principle
ambition of any reasonably pretty girl is to
have "on the string" more men than any of
her girl friends. Whether or not he was
right in this conclusion, I leave to the judgment of the experienced reader.
' He pleased her and she liked to have him
around (figuratively, of course). He often
managed to work more or less delicate compliments into the conversation, and I cannot
but give him credit for despersing obvious and
grey-hair compliments, such as "sweets to
the sweet" when he handed her a lem— I
mean a rose.
Once or twice in his life his 'soft nothings"
were really artistic. It was a long time before Clare—for that was the lady's name—
forgot what he said to her one night at her
garden-gate. He had brought her home from
a dance. It was summer and the moon was
full. (It is said that he emulated the moon
very shortly after saying farewell to Clare—
but that's neither here nor there.) At the
gate she took his hand and softly said:
"Arthur, you are an angel to bring me
home!" "You don't know how true that is,
Clare," The inhabitants of heaven are
angels, and when I'm with you, I'm in
heaven. And the Recording. Angel shook
with ill-suppressed laughter.
Were the plot of my tale less flimsy construction, I should not trouble about all these
details. But the actual story—and Arthur
Hamilton and Clare Fitzroy Montmorency
DeCourcy will vouch for the truth of it—is
but a wee little thing hardly able to stand
alone. And, therefore, I must tell you one
other fact about our Arthur, though, when I
come to think of it, that fact is the very stuff
and essence of our tale. He was a poet.
Stop! I am wrong. He was not a poet, but
thought he was one. Stop! I am wrong,

7

again. To do him justice he knew as well
as anyone that he was not a poet—but he
managed to persuade Clare that he was. For
the benefit of such of readers as may some
day wish to persuade a fair one that they are
invested with the cloak of genius, I may say
that she thought him a poet simply because
he dedicated all his verses to her. In The
Furor, the daily paper of their town, appeared lines "To C. Fitz. R. M. DeC."
When I first saw this title I felt sure my
friend "A. H." was addressing an Ode to
Cadmus, the originator of the Alphabet, but
the first read, "Come with me in my motorcar, fair lady mine, he said," which discouraged the Cadmus theory—particularly as
there was no mention of diagon's teeth; or of
any teeth but Clare's. These he apostophized
as "twin rows of pearls between coral lips!"
This rhymns with her "dainty finger tips,"
or "honey-dew sips," I forget which. When
Eve was created, such love-verses were
already worn out; for Adam had written
several Prondeaux to Lilith. Arthur knew
well how old his subject was—Love is as old
as the world; and calf, or puppy love originated when Adam's eldest son was 23 (obsit
omen!) and his eldest daughter a bit younger.
But Arthur, also, had the satisfaction of
knowing that Clare thought his effusions both
true and new.
Besides this he had an amazing method of
ransacking volumes of verse for a suitable
motto for some poem or other, and then
modestly admitting that his mind was stored
with gems from the poets. Taken all in all,
he suitably illustrates the heart-rendering
cry of a character in Dumasfl/s. `J'ai commis des vers; c'est effroyant!" I cannot close
this little character sketch without a single
specimen of his verse:
"The golden morn is blushful, soft the maiden
rose;
But there is a color that no artist can suppose;
No one can discover let him forever seek—
'Tis the flush of morning on her kiss inviting
cheek."
The most prejudical reader will admit that
this is remarkable. The first words introduce
us to a "golden blush" and in the last line
he mentions a color that truly "no artist
could suppose' —a complexion which could

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

not be "discovered" though sought for forever! And yet poor Arthur was rather proud
of that poem—indeed he actually wrote of it
to a close friend without fastening the word
"poem" in the stern embrace of two quotation marks.
But it is high time we tell our story.
Arthur left the little village where he had
loved and was destined to lose. He spent his
vacation, one summer, at East Gloucester.
There he wrote much; odes "'ts the Sea
Breaking upon Brace's Rock" et cetera, and
sent them to Clare in his far-off home. Then
came the deluge in the shape of another lady.
Rejoice, 0 reader, my story has begun! She
was lovely, and he took long walks with her
along Cape Ann, and sailed out on the "summer sea," as he wrote. (By the way, it is
noticeable that we read of "Spring Lake"
and "Summer Sea." Of course, he wrote
poetry to her; cela va sons dire. The weather
was hot, and he yielded to the temptation to
send her copies of old verses to his first love,
which he did conveniently, as her name, also,
was Clare. And thereby hangs my tale. To
be frank, it has hung so long that I should
think it would be suffocated by this time.
But once he felt truly inspired and he wrote
some new lines to her. They really were not
half bad; he even modestly saki it was "his
least bad effort," and Clare Number Two,
(her last name—we breathe it softly—was
Jones), heaved a soulful sigh and gently
whispered, "It is perfect, darling!" By
which you see that they were both far gone.
In his heart of hearts he thought so too; but
he kept his thoughts to himself. However,
he sent a copy to the Johns Hopkins NEwsLETTER, which was returned "with thanks."
One of the editors has told me that it was not
up to their standard. A little discouraged,
he mailed it to The Atlantic Monthly
where it appeared with an introduction by
Mr. Edmund Clarence Stedman; an editorial
of appreciation by Mr. Bliss Perry; and a
letter of recommendation by Mr. Austin Dobson. Mr. Lang mentioned it in his weekly
letter to the London Illustrated News. When
I:, asked the Editor-in-chief of the MimsLETTER why he had neglected such a masterpiece, he wearily placed one of his far-famed
"innumerable cigarettes" between his lips

and said: "We are always anxious to encourage young authors; but we simply can't
lower ourselves to such a degree as to accept
such stuff as the Atlantic Monthly takes."
Now, Clare Number One heard of her
Arthur's prowess, and she bought a copy of
the issue of The Atlantic containing the
lines, "To Clare," which, quite reasonably,
she thought were addressed to her, not knowing that at East Gloucester there was, in the
old phase, "another pebble on the beach."
In all seriousness there are many, as the feet
of any one who has been there can testify.
Clare subscribed to the Argus Clipping
Bureau, which sent her all reviews and mentions of her sweet-heart's poem. One day,
however, she opened a letter and a clipping
fell out as usual. It was cut from Mr.
Mabie's literary page of the Ladies' Home
Journal and read thus:
AN INTERESTING SIDELIGHT.
Announcement has been made that the
source of inspiration of Hamilton's "Clare,"
in which we view the combination and
culmination of the poetic theories of Charles
Baudelaire and Ella Wheeler Wilcox, is Miss
Clare Jones, of Omaha, now visiting near
Boston, and to whom Mr. Hamilton is
reported engaged.
Clare Fitezroy Montmorency DeCourcy was
stunned, but,retaining her dignity,she packed
up all the poems Arthur had sent her, and
expressed them to him,—they would not go by
mail, being over-weight.
Thus Arthur lost his first love. But he
cared not, being desperately enamoured of
Clara Jones. Her, too, he lost, and in a
singular way. His apostropies to her lovelines began to go too far; (and in this particular our story imitates his verse only too
well.) Finally in one burning letter he hailed
her as a "pearl enclosed in the oyster of thy
smile," and Miss Jones, who was a sensible
girl, saw that Arthur Hamilton was no poet,
but rather a tedious young man. So she tore
up his poems, accepted the proposal of a millionaire eye-glass maker, and, let us hope,
lived happily ever after.
As for Arthur, he writes no more poetry,
and "at the latest hearing" had just invented
a combinatibn cork-screw and ice-cream
freezer.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

BASE BALL PROSPECTS.
Spring is near at hand and finds everybody
eagerly awaiting the beginning of another
successful season for Hopkins "ball" team.
If money and nerve can make a successful
nine, Johns Hopkins University should have
one this year. For coach Merle T. Adkins
says that he has one of the best lot of candidates that he has ever seen at Hopkins. As
for money, Manager Henry P. Hinson says
that over two hundred dollars have been
received in cash. Since it is known that the
team needed only about a hundred and fifty
dollars, one can easily see that the uniforms,
thaterials, and other expenses incidental to
running a team, can be easily taken care of.
The candidates are numerous and fairly
regular at practices, and—what is especially
gratifying—there is a large number of undergraduates trying for the team. These are the
candidates: Black, Budd,Whitcraft, Guisberg,
Edlawitch, Baily, Gorslive, Maynard, Hardcastle, Webb, Wadkins, Elliot, Costello,
Nixon, Cole, Frey, Rhodes, Taylor, Meers
and Janney Smith.
Fridlay French might do some of the pitching, as he has good "control" and "curves."
However, Watkins will probably do the
pitching,as his "control" is improving and he
has great speed. Although Whitcraft is
doing well behind the bat, Webb having recovered from the injury to his thumb will
return to his old position. Cole, also, is expected to be in the battery, and Taylor is trying for pitcher. Elliot is probably the man
for first base, but Black and Baily will give
him a 'pretty good rub to hold the position.
Maynard and several others are trying for
second, and Costello is doing well at third.
Guisberg and Taylor show neat work at shortstop. Budd and Hardcastle will try to keep
their old places in the field while all the
others show great spirit and promise by the
way in which they are coming out.
The schedule will, probably, be announced
next week, and, as soon as the weather permits, practice will be held outdoors.
You have all paid your money—so, now,
come and support the team by your attendance and rooting!

THE MEET.
"The best we've ever had." That is the
verdict of the alumni and undergraduates
alike, and much credit is due to the committee, and, particularly, to Mr. Lynch, the
manager of the track team and chairman of
the games committee, All the arrangements
were fine: there was no scarcity of programs,
as last year; there was a band present to make
things more pleasant; the middle of floor was
not crowded and the events were run off with
little, if any, waits between them.
The University of Pennsylvania won the
meet with a score of thirteen points, ten of
which were made by Cartwell, their fast
sprinter. Swarthmore landed second, with
ten points. We got second place in the 220
handicap, and second in the handicap mile,
but Brenton was disqualified, after running a
remarkably fast race, from a scratch. His
over-anxiety kept him from winning and
breaking the state record, which he would
have easily done. Graves, in the quarter,
was well placed and might, very likely, have
won some points, had he not been tripped
just before he entered the straightway.
The best event, the prettiest race, was the
relay between Virginia and Hopkins. That
was the star event of the program, and it fully
came up to the expectations of everybody.
No better race has ever been run by any
Hopkins team, and all honor is due the four
who gave all they had last Saturday night.
Each man ran finely, and each man showed
the grit and nerve in him. Never were the
runners more than three yards apart, and now
Virginia and now Hopkins would be in the
lead. It was a race that any team might be
proud to say they ran in, victors or losers.
No one can say that support from the rooters
was lacking, after the way those rooters
swarmed out on the track and yelled, and
marched in lock step, led by the flag, and then
yelled again. Every rooter,—and there were
some there who had not been in college for
several years,—yelled himself hoarse as he encouraged the 'Varsity to greater effort. With
such spirit behind them, the four ran a race
such as is seldom seen in this town. B. J.
Wefers,'the old Georgetown sprinter, who
has seen relay after relay race, said that he
had never seen a better one, and his remark

UNIVERSITY NOTES.

STUDENT CONTRIBUTION FUND.

Not long ago, when the Cleveland Flyer on
the Pennsylvania Railroad was wrecked near
St. Louis, one of those who happened to be
sent out to patch up the wreck was Gibson
Sisco, '02. While working, he came across
B. Swayne Putts, '02, Med. '06, who had
been sent out to patch up the injured, all of
which goes to prove that the world is a small
place, after all, and that Hopkins men are
fairly well scattered over it.

The closing of the cage door has been a
good move for the different teams using the
cage. No longer do you see a knot of spectators gathered on the track near the door
obstructing the path and dodging the lacrosse
balls. Lookers-on must take the balcony
now, giving the teams full use of the floor.
The cinder-path, also, is thus kept in
better condition, since the tracking of ordinary shoes is none too good for it.

There is soon to be another Hopkins night.
The General Atheletic Association and the
class of 1907 will unite to give one sometime
in the near future. The committee appointed
is as follows: Distler, Graner and Gould for
the Senior class, and Bridgman, Chesney and
Maynard for the Athletic Board. Here is
just the chance to have another good time,
and we won't have any snow this trip to
spoil the night for us. With combined forces
this Hopkins night ought excel the other
and make money for the Athletic Association
and for the Hullabaloo. It is to be hoped
that next year's Senior class will follow the
example set, and have several such nights
throughout the year. Everybody must be on
hand for this occasion, Alumni, Graduates,
Seniors,Juniors, Freshmen and Specials,—not
excepting the Faculty.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

12

THE Y. M. C. A. RECEPTION.
The annual reception to the members was
given by the Y. M. C. A. in Levering Hall,
February 20, 1907. Not all the members or
speakers were present, due in part, as Dr.
Brush said, to the Boston Symphony. Those
who were present listened to a number of
negro stories by Dr. Ballagh, who proved to
be quite an entertainer. Dr. Brush helped
the cause along with a story or so that was
perfectly proper. The Mandolin Club then
came over from their practice in McCoy Hall,
and gave a selection. Dr. Matthews, next,
told us of bluffs that he had made out in the
west, twelve miles from nowhere, and added
a little advice on the science of bluffing. The
guests then adjourned to the piano and
several attempts were made at close harmony,
but there was little success, for what could
they do with the thought of eight gallons of
ice cream, not to mention numerous plates of
cake, distracting their minds? When the
feed was over, it was found that there was
enough ice-cream left to take home to mother,
and to provide a lunch for the General Secretary the next day. Soon after, the affair

RESIDENT GILMAN, in enumerating the branches of knowledge
with which an educated man should be acquainted recommended a
practical acquaintance with two modern languages—French and
German. No one could dispute this opinion, for whether he be a
student of Philosophy, of Physics, of Latin or Greek, or, even, of
English literature he knows that stores of information are behind
doors opening only to German and French keys.
Now, if an instructor were asked what is the greatest help in
getting a hold on a language, he would, doubtless, answer "An
ability to understand the language when spoken. Go to France, to
people
talk, and, then, when you pick up a book you will begin to
the
Germany, listen to
understand what your foreign friend wishes to tell you." But how many of the students can
take this wholesome advice? Only a small part. For this reason it is, perhaps, that the University turns the table, and tries to bring France and Germany to us. Monsieur Janier gives us a
number of lectures and, following him, comes Dr. Kiihnemann, from both of whom we derive
no little help. Hence, as undergraduate students, we can see that if we could listen regularly
to French and German, it would be a question of but a short time till everyone would understand, at least, a simple discourse and be able to speak more or less fluently.
We cannot expect, however; constant imfiortations, nor do we think it necessary. Among
the faculty are men who are either German or French by birth, or who have sufficiently mastered
one or the other language to feel no hesitation in talking or reading to us for several hours a
week.
•
Various plans could be adopted, the talks or readings could be graded to suit the
vocabularies of the hearers; regular attendance could be secured by making this a part of the
regular course and requiring a brief synopsis of the lecture,—anything that would insure a more
thorough acquaintance with the languages during the undergraduate years.
We feel that this is a real need, and would respectfully request the faculty to take this
matter into consideration.

THE COCK FIGHT.
What call you the king of sports, boys
The highest, by far, of all our joys?
When fancy-free and out for fun,
Is it not cock-fighting, ten to one?
On a blustery, windy winter's night
When no one's looking, and no one's in sight,
Down to some dreary barn we go,
Where round about howl the winds, and blow.
Securely fastening the barn door,
We throw our cocks upon the floor.
Tnen flash of steel in the din lamp-light,
A click of steel against brain,
Triumphant crow of the victor cock,—
And all is still again.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE THIRTY-FIRST ANNIVERSARY

CELEBRATION.
The audience that assembled in McCoy
Hall on February 22nd to see the commeration exercises found a notable assembly. Of
the five divisions of the procession that filed
in between the lines of undergraduate students,
the first, directly following Chief Marshal
Edward B. Mathews, consisted of President
Remsen and Governor Warfield, walking
abreast. Behind these were Mr. R. Brent
Keyser, President of the board of trustees of
the University, and Cardinal Gibbons, Mr.
Blanchard Randall, President of the Baltimore
Chamber of Commerce, and Attorney-General
Charles J. Bonaparte, President Emeritus
Daniel C. Gilman and Professor Hannis
Taylor, Mr. Joshua Levering and Mayor
Timanus, Dean Edward H. Griffin and Mr.
William H. Buckler. Following these were
the other members of the board of trustees,
and the faculty of the university. The second
division was made up of the alumni and
candidates for degrees; the third consisted of
the graduate students in philosophy; the
fourth, of the students in medicine; and the
fifth, of the undergraduates.
The musical program was under the direction
of Mr. Edwin Litchfield Turnbull, who conducted an orchestra of twenty-seven pieces.
National airs began to be heard from the lobby
as the procession, at 10.45 a. m., proceeded
to the main hall, and, during the intervals
between the exercises, the orchestra rendered
several carefully prepared selections.
After the offering of the invocation by the
Reverend Edward Barnes Niver, rector of
Christ Church, President Remsen introduced
the orator of the day, Professor Hannis Taylor,
formerly United States Minister to Spain and
a member of the committee on the settlement
of the Spanish war claims.
Professor Taylor's speech was a strong and
interesting presentation of the "Relation of
the South to Pending Problems." In regard
to the question of controlling by legislation
those bewildering millions that lie at the disposal of private individuals, he said: "It is
the States alone that have the constitutional
power to deal with such questions, and, in the
present condition of rapid inter-communication, the necessary concert of action is not at

all impossible. No nobler work could be
undertaken by the American Bar Association,
which has the machinery necessary for the
making of an immediate beginning."
When the selection, which followed this
address, had been concluded by the orchestra,
the degree of Doctor of Philosophy was
was awarded to Mr. Alfred Allan Kerns
(Randolph-Mown, '98) and to Mr. Louis
Bernard Wolfenson (University of Wisconsin,
'01). It was also announced that Miss
Straight had received her degree of Doctor of
Medicine.
When the degrees had been awarded, President Remsen rose to read the list of announcements. In regard to money for moving to
Homewood, Dr. Remsen saki emphatically
that he had nothing definite to announce.
However, he went on to say that there are
'things in the air,' and it remains for us only
to pull them down. It was also announced
that Dr. John C. Hilde had won the Henrico
medallion, his dissertation being upon the
"Early Diplomatic Relations of the United
States with Spain."
Mr. William H. Buckler, as chairman of
the committee on Homewood, reported that
an accurate togographical survey of the whole
property had been made, that the athletic
field was now rapidly rounding into shape
and will be in condition for foot-ball in the
fall, and, also, that the plans have been made
for a series of botanical gardens.
A cablegram, received from Professors
Wilson, Mayoffin, Moore and Spencer, Hopkins men engaged in research in the classical
school at Rome, was then read, as was, also,
an announcement of a gift for the purchase of
archaeological specimens from Italy.
In the evening the Hopkins Alumni held
their annual banquet at the Merchant's Club,
where, according to all accounts, they had a
most enjoyable reunion.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

INTERCOLLEGIATE CONFERENCE.
Levering Hall has, again, been selected as
the place of meeting of an Intercollegiate
Missionary Conference. The Conference will
convene on Saturday, March 9, and continue
till Sunday evening.
Delegates have been invited from the following institutions: Western Maryland,
Maryland Agricultural and Delaware Colleges;
George Washington University, Jacob Tome
Institute, Charlotte Hall School, Wilmington
Conference Academy, New Windsor College,
United States Naval Academy. St. John's
College, Woman's Colleges of Baltimore,
Frederick and Lutherville. Besides these, all
the local medical schools will be represented.
The speakers at the Conference will be Mr.
Fennell P. Turner, Secretary of the Student
Volunteer Movement; Mr. Staub, one of the
traveling secretaries of the Movement; Dr.
Marion J. Kline, Secretary of the Lutheran
Board of Foreign Missions, and others.
The program promises to be one of unusual
interest. The opening session, at 2.30 p. m.,
Saturday, will be devoted to addresses and
discussions, and will be followed by a supper
for the official delegates. In the evening
there will be a public meeting for students.
The Sunday morning session will be held in
conjunction with the Students' Bible Class of
Mt. Vernon M. E. Church at 10 o'clock. At
3 p. m., in Levering Hall, will be held a session for Student Volunteers. The evening
session at 7 o'clock will be held in the chapel
of the First M. E. Church.
Hopkins students are invited, especially, to
the Saturday evening, Sunday morning and
evening sessions.
The many phases of missionary work will
be treated in this Conference. Mr. Turner's
wide experience enables him to speak authoritatively on missionary work in all foreign
lands. The other speakers will deal with
mission study which has become so popular in
the last few years and with the training of
Volunteers.

Mr. Robert E. Speer, the noted speaker to
college students, will preach at Brown
Memorial Presbyterian Church on March 17.

Seats will be reserved for students until 7.45
p. m. No man can afford to miss hearing
him.

CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION
REUNION.

MEMBERS'

The annual reunion of members of the
Christian Association was held in Levering
Hall February 20th. The fellows and a number of the faculty joined in an informal social
evening. Drs. Ballagh and Mathews gave
interesting talks, Dr. Brush presided. The
Mandolin Club played in good style, after
which all sang Hopkins songs, and enjoyed
refreshments.

BIBLE AND MISSION STUDY CLASSES.
Three Bible classes are meeting regularly
each week, one of which is under the auspices
of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew.
Two mission study classes have been
started. One under the leadership of Dr. L.
C. Ballet is studying Dr. Grose's book,
"Aliens or Americans ?" This book deals
with the problems of immigration and their
bearing upon home missions. The other
class is studying the latest work in foreign
lands. It is being conducted by the General
Secretary.
The attention of Hopkins students is called
to the morning Chapel exercises. Every man
is invited to attend. A little effort will be required to get down by 8.45 a. m., but "get
the habit," and it soon becomes easy.

The Student Handbooks received this year
from other colleges will be placed on exhibition in Levering Hall.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE SEA.
"The light, and sound, and darkness of the sea."
[Swinburne.]

I.
When the gods on high had created the land
And gave life to the sounding deep,
And ordained the day as a time for work,
And night as a time for sleep,
They gave man joy that he might laugh,
And sorrow that he might weep.
Thanksgiving arose from valleys and hills,
And caves echo praises again;
Creation rejoiced, and joyful sang,—
Save the Might of the murmuring main;—
The gods had created and formed it;
Tried to rule it—but ever in vain.
Though the mists render thanks as they rise
from the vale,
And clouds as they float o'er the hill,
Though the wind giveth praises aloud and
afar,
And the violet lowly and still,
The sound of the sea, with its surges and
swell,
Bends not to the heavenly will.
IV.
But ever and ever, while dashing in spray,
Or roaring tumultous afar;
In the brightness of noon, in night and in
storm,
By the light of a lingering star,
They rise up against the decree of the gods
In melodious thunderous war!
—S. C. C.

THE POOR EDITOR.
At a recent editorial convention a member
offered the following toast: "To save an
editor from starvation, take his paper and
pay for it promptly. To save him from bankruptcy, advertise in his paper liberally. To
save him from despair, send him every news
item of which you can get hold. To save
him from wrath, write your correspondence
plainly on one side of the sheet and send it in
as early as possible. To save him from mistakes, bury him. Dead people are the only
ones who never make any mistakes."—Exchange.

THE CANADIAN GUIDE.
He knows no power to bid him stay,
Where'er he will—there lies his way.
No social ties have bound his soul—
Within himself, his life, his goal.
His hearth the camp-fire in the gloam,
The star-watched wilderness his home.
His is that freedom large, sublime,
That was before the count of time.
His strength is as the hills secure,
And like the hills he can endure.
Might, courage. honesty—he sees
In men no virtues, saving these.
No learning has he, yet would I
Fain rise to his philosophy.
He knows no music save the wild
Strange songs he heard when once a child.
Or those weird tunes the logmen sing,
Borne down the river with the spring.
And yet a savage poetry lies
On his few words, and in his eyes.
Whence came he? that lie cannot say—
"Somewhere to Northward and away."
And whither goes? He cannot tell,
For him the present time is well.
He cares not for the passing years,
Their blight he neither knows nor fears.
For him 'tis fated not to die
A weak man's death, but, 'neath the sky,
To sink upon some roaring flood,
And rise unsullied to his God.
—W. B. M.

THE POSTMAN.
The postman is a funny man
Who never does things right;
The things he brings on time we wish
Had never met our sight.
The bills and such and postal cards
That bear the college seal
Are always brought in perfect time
With sadly misplaced zeal.
But checks from home and notes from 'Her"
Don't come in such a drive,
And though we're sure that they were sent
They somehow don't arrive.—Lampoon.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

MODERN LOVE.
(With apologies to Mr. George Meredith.)

She was rather an unsophisticated little
lady, and decidedy ingenious. For a long
time Arthur Hamilton had fancied himself in
love with her, and she took little pains to conceal the pleasure which his conventional
protestations of adoration" gave her, although at first she was quite heart-free herself. Arthur found himself, as he grow older,
coming to the conclusion that the principle
ambition of any reasonably pretty girl is to
have "on the string" more men than any of
her girl friends. Whether or not he was
right in this conclusion, I leave to the judgment of the experienced reader.
' He pleased her and she liked to have him
around (figuratively, of course). He often
managed to work more or less delicate compliments into the conversation, and I cannot
but give him credit for despersing obvious and
grey-hair compliments, such as "sweets to
the sweet" when he handed her a lem— I
mean a rose.
Once or twice in his life his 'soft nothings"
were really artistic. It was a long time before Clare—for that was the lady's name—
forgot what he said to her one night at her
garden-gate. He had brought her home from
a dance. It was summer and the moon was
full. (It is said that he emulated the moon
very shortly after saying farewell to Clare—
but that's neither here nor there.) At the
gate she took his hand and softly said:
"Arthur, you are an angel to bring me
home!" "You don't know how true that is,
Clare," The inhabitants of heaven are
angels, and when I'm with you, I'm in
heaven. And the Recording. Angel shook
with ill-suppressed laughter.
Were the plot of my tale less flimsy construction, I should not trouble about all these
details. But the actual story—and Arthur
Hamilton and Clare Fitzroy Montmorency
DeCourcy will vouch for the truth of it—is
but a wee little thing hardly able to stand
alone. And, therefore, I must tell you one
other fact about our Arthur, though, when I
come to think of it, that fact is the very stuff
and essence of our tale. He was a poet.
Stop! I am wrong. He was not a poet, but
thought he was one. Stop! I am wrong,

7

again. To do him justice he knew as well
as anyone that he was not a poet—but he
managed to persuade Clare that he was. For
the benefit of such of readers as may some
day wish to persuade a fair one that they are
invested with the cloak of genius, I may say
that she thought him a poet simply because
he dedicated all his verses to her. In The
Furor, the daily paper of their town, appeared lines "To C. Fitz. R. M. DeC."
When I first saw this title I felt sure my
friend "A. H." was addressing an Ode to
Cadmus, the originator of the Alphabet, but
the first read, "Come with me in my motorcar, fair lady mine, he said," which discouraged the Cadmus theory—particularly as
there was no mention of diagon's teeth; or of
any teeth but Clare's. These he apostophized
as "twin rows of pearls between coral lips!"
This rhymns with her "dainty finger tips,"
or "honey-dew sips," I forget which. When
Eve was created, such love-verses were
already worn out; for Adam had written
several Prondeaux to Lilith. Arthur knew
well how old his subject was—Love is as old
as the world; and calf, or puppy love originated when Adam's eldest son was 23 (obsit
omen!) and his eldest daughter a bit younger.
But Arthur, also, had the satisfaction of
knowing that Clare thought his effusions both
true and new.
Besides this he had an amazing method of
ransacking volumes of verse for a suitable
motto for some poem or other, and then
modestly admitting that his mind was stored
with gems from the poets. Taken all in all,
he suitably illustrates the heart-rendering
cry of a character in Dumasfl/s. `J'ai commis des vers; c'est effroyant!" I cannot close
this little character sketch without a single
specimen of his verse:
"The golden morn is blushful, soft the maiden
rose;
But there is a color that no artist can suppose;
No one can discover let him forever seek—
'Tis the flush of morning on her kiss inviting
cheek."
The most prejudical reader will admit that
this is remarkable. The first words introduce
us to a "golden blush" and in the last line
he mentions a color that truly "no artist
could suppose' —a complexion which could

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

not be "discovered" though sought for forever! And yet poor Arthur was rather proud
of that poem—indeed he actually wrote of it
to a close friend without fastening the word
"poem" in the stern embrace of two quotation marks.
But it is high time we tell our story.
Arthur left the little village where he had
loved and was destined to lose. He spent his
vacation, one summer, at East Gloucester.
There he wrote much; odes "'ts the Sea
Breaking upon Brace's Rock" et cetera, and
sent them to Clare in his far-off home. Then
came the deluge in the shape of another lady.
Rejoice, 0 reader, my story has begun! She
was lovely, and he took long walks with her
along Cape Ann, and sailed out on the "summer sea," as he wrote. (By the way, it is
noticeable that we read of "Spring Lake"
and "Summer Sea." Of course, he wrote
poetry to her; cela va sons dire. The weather
was hot, and he yielded to the temptation to
send her copies of old verses to his first love,
which he did conveniently, as her name, also,
was Clare. And thereby hangs my tale. To
be frank, it has hung so long that I should
think it would be suffocated by this time.
But once he felt truly inspired and he wrote
some new lines to her. They really were not
half bad; he even modestly saki it was "his
least bad effort," and Clare Number Two,
(her last name—we breathe it softly—was
Jones), heaved a soulful sigh and gently
whispered, "It is perfect, darling!" By
which you see that they were both far gone.
In his heart of hearts he thought so too; but
he kept his thoughts to himself. However,
he sent a copy to the Johns Hopkins NEwsLETTER, which was returned "with thanks."
One of the editors has told me that it was not
up to their standard. A little discouraged,
he mailed it to The Atlantic Monthly
where it appeared with an introduction by
Mr. Edmund Clarence Stedman; an editorial
of appreciation by Mr. Bliss Perry; and a
letter of recommendation by Mr. Austin Dobson. Mr. Lang mentioned it in his weekly
letter to the London Illustrated News. When
I:, asked the Editor-in-chief of the MimsLETTER why he had neglected such a masterpiece, he wearily placed one of his far-famed
"innumerable cigarettes" between his lips

and said: "We are always anxious to encourage young authors; but we simply can't
lower ourselves to such a degree as to accept
such stuff as the Atlantic Monthly takes."
Now, Clare Number One heard of her
Arthur's prowess, and she bought a copy of
the issue of The Atlantic containing the
lines, "To Clare," which, quite reasonably,
she thought were addressed to her, not knowing that at East Gloucester there was, in the
old phase, "another pebble on the beach."
In all seriousness there are many, as the feet
of any one who has been there can testify.
Clare subscribed to the Argus Clipping
Bureau, which sent her all reviews and mentions of her sweet-heart's poem. One day,
however, she opened a letter and a clipping
fell out as usual. It was cut from Mr.
Mabie's literary page of the Ladies' Home
Journal and read thus:
AN INTERESTING SIDELIGHT.
Announcement has been made that the
source of inspiration of Hamilton's "Clare,"
in which we view the combination and
culmination of the poetic theories of Charles
Baudelaire and Ella Wheeler Wilcox, is Miss
Clare Jones, of Omaha, now visiting near
Boston, and to whom Mr. Hamilton is
reported engaged.
Clare Fitezroy Montmorency DeCourcy was
stunned, but,retaining her dignity,she packed
up all the poems Arthur had sent her, and
expressed them to him,—they would not go by
mail, being over-weight.
Thus Arthur lost his first love. But he
cared not, being desperately enamoured of
Clara Jones. Her, too, he lost, and in a
singular way. His apostropies to her lovelines began to go too far; (and in this particular our story imitates his verse only too
well.) Finally in one burning letter he hailed
her as a "pearl enclosed in the oyster of thy
smile," and Miss Jones, who was a sensible
girl, saw that Arthur Hamilton was no poet,
but rather a tedious young man. So she tore
up his poems, accepted the proposal of a millionaire eye-glass maker, and, let us hope,
lived happily ever after.
As for Arthur, he writes no more poetry,
and "at the latest hearing" had just invented
a combinatibn cork-screw and ice-cream
freezer.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

BASE BALL PROSPECTS.
Spring is near at hand and finds everybody
eagerly awaiting the beginning of another
successful season for Hopkins "ball" team.
If money and nerve can make a successful
nine, Johns Hopkins University should have
one this year. For coach Merle T. Adkins
says that he has one of the best lot of candidates that he has ever seen at Hopkins. As
for money, Manager Henry P. Hinson says
that over two hundred dollars have been
received in cash. Since it is known that the
team needed only about a hundred and fifty
dollars, one can easily see that the uniforms,
thaterials, and other expenses incidental to
running a team, can be easily taken care of.
The candidates are numerous and fairly
regular at practices, and—what is especially
gratifying—there is a large number of undergraduates trying for the team. These are the
candidates: Black, Budd,Whitcraft, Guisberg,
Edlawitch, Baily, Gorslive, Maynard, Hardcastle, Webb, Wadkins, Elliot, Costello,
Nixon, Cole, Frey, Rhodes, Taylor, Meers
and Janney Smith.
Fridlay French might do some of the pitching, as he has good "control" and "curves."
However, Watkins will probably do the
pitching,as his "control" is improving and he
has great speed. Although Whitcraft is
doing well behind the bat, Webb having recovered from the injury to his thumb will
return to his old position. Cole, also, is expected to be in the battery, and Taylor is trying for pitcher. Elliot is probably the man
for first base, but Black and Baily will give
him a 'pretty good rub to hold the position.
Maynard and several others are trying for
second, and Costello is doing well at third.
Guisberg and Taylor show neat work at shortstop. Budd and Hardcastle will try to keep
their old places in the field while all the
others show great spirit and promise by the
way in which they are coming out.
The schedule will, probably, be announced
next week, and, as soon as the weather permits, practice will be held outdoors.
You have all paid your money—so, now,
come and support the team by your attendance and rooting!

THE MEET.
"The best we've ever had." That is the
verdict of the alumni and undergraduates
alike, and much credit is due to the committee, and, particularly, to Mr. Lynch, the
manager of the track team and chairman of
the games committee, All the arrangements
were fine: there was no scarcity of programs,
as last year; there was a band present to make
things more pleasant; the middle of floor was
not crowded and the events were run off with
little, if any, waits between them.
The University of Pennsylvania won the
meet with a score of thirteen points, ten of
which were made by Cartwell, their fast
sprinter. Swarthmore landed second, with
ten points. We got second place in the 220
handicap, and second in the handicap mile,
but Brenton was disqualified, after running a
remarkably fast race, from a scratch. His
over-anxiety kept him from winning and
breaking the state record, which he would
have easily done. Graves, in the quarter,
was well placed and might, very likely, have
won some points, had he not been tripped
just before he entered the straightway.
The best event, the prettiest race, was the
relay between Virginia and Hopkins. That
was the star event of the program, and it fully
came up to the expectations of everybody.
No better race has ever been run by any
Hopkins team, and all honor is due the four
who gave all they had last Saturday night.
Each man ran finely, and each man showed
the grit and nerve in him. Never were the
runners more than three yards apart, and now
Virginia and now Hopkins would be in the
lead. It was a race that any team might be
proud to say they ran in, victors or losers.
No one can say that support from the rooters
was lacking, after the way those rooters
swarmed out on the track and yelled, and
marched in lock step, led by the flag, and then
yelled again. Every rooter,—and there were
some there who had not been in college for
several years,—yelled himself hoarse as he encouraged the 'Varsity to greater effort. With
such spirit behind them, the four ran a race
such as is seldom seen in this town. B. J.
Wefers,'the old Georgetown sprinter, who
has seen relay after relay race, said that he
had never seen a better one, and his remark

UNIVERSITY NOTES.

STUDENT CONTRIBUTION FUND.

Not long ago, when the Cleveland Flyer on
the Pennsylvania Railroad was wrecked near
St. Louis, one of those who happened to be
sent out to patch up the wreck was Gibson
Sisco, '02. While working, he came across
B. Swayne Putts, '02, Med. '06, who had
been sent out to patch up the injured, all of
which goes to prove that the world is a small
place, after all, and that Hopkins men are
fairly well scattered over it.

Messrs. Costell, Ridgely and Stewart have
been awarded the 'H." for football. Messrs.
C. .Sawyer Jarvis, Chesney and Abel have
been a warded "H. A. A. S." Mr. Mears
has been awarded the track "H. A. A." for
work in Fifth Regiment Meet.

The closing of the cage door has been a
good move for the different teams using the
cage. No longer do you see a knot of spectators gathered on the track near the door
obstructing the path and dodging the lacrosse
balls. Lookers-on must take the balcony
now, giving the teams full use of the floor.
The cinder-path, also, is thus kept in
better condition, since the tracking of ordinary shoes is none too good for it.

There is soon to be another Hopkins night.
The General Atheletic Association and the
class of 1907 will unite to give one sometime
in the near future. The committee appointed
is as follows: Distler, Graner and Gould for
the Senior class, and Bridgman, Chesney and
Maynard for the Athletic Board. Here is
just the chance to have another good time,
and we won't have any snow this trip to
spoil the night for us. With combined forces
this Hopkins night ought excel the other
and make money for the Athletic Association
and for the Hullabaloo. It is to be hoped
that next year's Senior class will follow the
example set, and have several such nights
throughout the year. Everybody must be on
hand for this occasion, Alumni, Graduates,
Seniors,Juniors, Freshmen and Specials,—not
excepting the Faculty.

THE Y. M. C. A. RECEPTION.
The annual reception to the members was
given by the Y. M. C. A. in Levering Hall,
February 20, 1907. Not all the members or
speakers were present, due in part, as Dr.
Brush said, to the Boston Symphony. Those
who were present listened to a number of
negro stories by Dr. Ballagh, who proved to
be quite an entertainer. Dr. Brush helped
the cause along with a story or so that was
perfectly proper. The Mandolin Club then
came over from their practice in McCoy Hall,
and gave a selection. Dr. Matthews, next,
told us of bluffs that he had made out in the
west, twelve miles from nowhere, and added
a little advice on the science of bluffing. The
guests then adjourned to the piano and
several attempts were made at close harmony,
but there was little success, for what could
they do with the thought of eight gallons of
ice cream, not to mention numerous plates of
cake, distracting their minds? When the
feed was over, it was found that there was
enough ice-cream left to take home to mother,
and to provide a lunch for the General Secretary the next day. Soon after, the affair
